Getting Started

Let's quickly see how we can get started with QueFlow

#Installation #Quick Start

Installation

To install QueFlow, you either can use CDN, go to its GitHub repository or direct download.


Using CDN

CDN is the fastest way to install a library. Just copy and paste the below code into the head section of your HTML file.


<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/Dayson9/QueFlowJS@main/QueFlow.min.js"></script>

Quick Start

QueFlowJS is a lightweight library which has 3 core methods: iRender(), Render(), and createSignal().


Create a reactive data with the createSignal() method. The createSignal() method only accepts one argument, which is the reactive data.





Easily render UI using the Render() method. This method accepts only two arguments, which is the HTML string to render and the element to render it on.


The API Reference

QueFlow has just 3 core methods for managing and rendering reactive state UI.

  1. Render()
  2. iRender()
  3. createSignal()

The Render() method


The Render() method is primarily used for parsing html/jsx content into an element.


Syntax: Render( jsx , parentSelector )

### Parameters:

1. `jsx` (string): Required. The JSX code that needs to be rendered onto the DOM.

2. `parentSelector` (string): Required. The CSS selector for the parent element where the JSX code will be rendered.


The Render() function in QueFlowJS is used to render JSX (JavaScript XML) code onto the specified parent element in the HTML document.


For example:





Note:

- Before calling Render(), make sure that all necessary components and data bindings are properly defined in the JSX code.

- It's important to ensure that the correct parent selector is provided to render the JSX content in the desired location on the webpage.


By following these steps, you can effectively use the Render() function provided by QueFlowJS to render dynamic content onto your webpage using JSX syntax.





The Render() function can also be called multiple times.





Warning ‚ö†Ô∏è

While the Render() method is very useful, you must be very careful while using it.

An attacker might pose a threat by trying to inject malicious code into your site.

To prevent that, make sure all inputs are sanitized or filtered before use.

The iRender() method



Syntax: iRender( app )


Parameters

- `app` (string): It represents the query selector of the DOM element where the HTML template will be rendered.



The iRender() function is a method that is used to render an HTML template provided inside a specified DOM element, considering the presence of data bindings defined with double curly braces `{{ }}`.


Usage

To use the `iRender()` method, you can call it with a valid CSS selector as its argument, indicating the DOM element where you want to render an HTML template with data bindings.


Example:



Note

- Make sure that your HTML template contains data bindings in the format `{{data}}` or {{data.key}} to take advantage of dynamic rendering using this method.

- Ensure that any necessary stylesheets are included in your HTML document before using this method to render your templates correctly.


Another Example:



To see the iRender() method in action, you can try out the live demo on codepen.

The createSignal() method


The `createSignal()` method is a part of the QueFlowJS library, which provides functionality for data binding and reactivity in JavaScript applications.

It creates a proxy object using the `Proxy` constructor to monitor changes to the target object and trigger updates in the DOM based on those changes.



Syntax: createSignal( data )


- `data` (object): A JavaScript object or value that you want to make reactive.


Return Value : (object)

The `createSignal()` method returns a proxy object that wraps the provided data. Any changes made to this proxy object will trigger updates in the DOM based on predefined templates and conditions.



Example Usage





Usage Recommendations


- The `createSignal()` method is particularly useful for building reactive interfaces and components where changes in data should automatically trigger updates in the UI.

- It is essential to define templates within your HTML or JSX content that will be monitored by the QueFlow library for dynamic updates.

- Ensure that proper event handling and conditions are set up within your templates to control how updates are applied based on data changes.



By integrating the `createSignal()` method into your JavaScript applications, you can achieve seamless reactivity and data binding capabilities with ease.

To see the createSignal() method in action, you can try out the live demo on codepen.
